name: Probability Mass Function (PMF)
description: Let $X$ be a discrete $\mathbb{R^d}$ random variable defined on $(\Omega, \mathbb{P})$. Suppose the discrete random variable can take on values $\{x_k\}_{k=0}^K$ each with probabilities $\{p_k\}_{k=0}^K$. Recall that a discrete random variable has a CDF of the form: $$F_X(t)=\sum_{k=0}^Kp_k\cdot\mathbb{1}(t\geq x_k)$$ Note that $\sum_k p_k=1$ must be true. Then we say that the probability mass function is the ordered sequence $\{p_k\}_{k=0}^K$ which effectively describes the distribution of our discrete random variable. The following relation expresses this property more clearly: $$p_k=\mathbb{P}(\{\omega\in\Omega : X(\omega)=x_k\})$$
